questions.text: The patient has a sudden, almost total occlusion of his right ICA. Brain tissue in which cerebral artery territory is likely to be affected most by resultant ischemia:
questions.correct_answer: C. Watershed between ACA and MCA
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Watershed between ACA and MCA Right ICA supplies blood to both the right ACA and MCA . Decreased blood supply to both ACA and MCA would most severely damage the tissue that lies between the distribution of 2 arteries. This area is known as a watershed area. The watershed territory between the MCA and ACA corresponds to the shoulder and hip girdle muscles on the motor homunculus, leading to a characteristic clinical deficit, and weakness of the shoulder and hip girdle muscles bilaterally.

Highyeild:

Anterior cerebral artery occlusion- The ACA is divided into two segments: precommunal (A1) circle of Willis, or stem, which connects the internal carotid artery to the anterior communicating artery- gives rise to several deep penetrating branches that supply the anterior limb of the internal capsule, the anterior perforated substance, amygdala, the anterior hypothalamus, and the inferior part of the head of the caudate nucleus. Occlusion of the proximal ACA is usually well tolerated because of collateral flow through the anterior communicating artery and collaterals through the MCA and PCA. postcommunal (A2) segment distal to the anterior communicating artery - A2 segment lesion C/L weakness- head and foot C/L sensory loss-head and foot Gait Apraxia Abulia- delayed verbal and motor response C/L grasp and suctioning reflex present Sensory -motor area of paracentral lobule damage- Urinary incontinence. Azygos A2/Single A2 present/ Bilateral ACA occlusion Paraplegia Urinary incontinence Abulia Personality change Primitive reflex present Middle cerebral artery occlusion- Inferior division of MCA occlusion- Dominant hemisphere→Wernicke’s Aphasia No weakness/ hemianesthesia Homonymous superior Quadrantanopia Dominant hemisphere-Gerstmann syndrome Non-dominant hemisphere-Spatial agnosia, hemineglect. Superior division of MCA occlusion- Broca’s aphasia C/L hemiplegia-dominant MCA lesion]C/L weakness-Hand and arm> Leg: Brachial syndrome Face weakness Sensory loss: Hand and arm >Leg Homonymous inferior quadrantanopia.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Territory supplied by ACA-Total occlusion of right ICA will not affect ACA. Option B. Territory supplied by MCA - Total occlusion of right ICA will not affect just ACA. Option D. Watershed between MCA and PCA- The posterior cerebral arteries (PCA) are the terminal branches of the basilar artery and supply the occipital lobes and posteromedial temporal lobes.

questions.text: 65/Male, was brought to the casualty with c/o left hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and non-fluent aphasia. The time of onset of symptoms is 3 hours. Further workup of the patient reveals a right proximal MCA occlusion. What is the best treatment plan?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

tPA followed by Thrombectomy Since the patient has presented within the golden period < 4.5 hours and no other contraindications were mentioned for thrombolysis and also no bleeding on workup, therefore thrombolysis is indicated in this patient. However recently there is also a role of mechanical thrombectomy if, on revision angiogram, there is still an occlusion after thrombolysis . Hence Option D is the best option

Highyeild:

Acute Stroke Management: Once a stroke is suspected, The first priorities are to assess airway and blood pressure , followed by establishing the time last seen normal. Patients with disabling neurologic deficits (particularly with the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale >5 ) may be eligible for thrombolytic or endovascular therapy. Based on the onset time, we follow the protocol shown in the figure. Management of acute stroke BA, basilar artery; CTP, computed tomography perfusion; ICA, internal carotid artery; IV, intravenous; M1, middle cerebral artery first division; M2, middle cerebral artery second division; PA, plasminogen activator. Following acute treatments, if any, we proceed with establishing the cause of the ischemic stroke. Blood pressure control should target systolic blood pressure <120 mmHg long-term, but we allow permissive hypertension for the first few weeks to help with the collateral flow to the brain.

If, on revision angiography , there is still an occlusion after thrombolysis then thrombectomy can be done.So, option D is better than thrombectomy alone

'Depending on the country, IV rtPA may be approved for up to 4.5 h with additional restrictions. A dose of 0.6 mg/kg is commonly used in Asia (Japan and China) based on randomized data indicating less haemorrhage and similar efficacy using this lower dose. questions.text: Binswanger's disease represents vascular dementia affecting which of the following -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gray Matter Binswanger’s disease is extremely severe diffuse white matter vascular injury.

Highyeild:

Binswanger’s disease or subcortical arteriosclerotic encephalopathy, Extremely severe diffuse white matter vascular injury gradual cognitive deterioration and notable white matter changes of small-vessel ischemic disease. White matter hyperintensities on T2-weighted or FLAIR MRI sequences are an almost ubiquitous feature of ageing . Although these lesions are readily visible on clinical MRI, they represent a nonspecific marker of white matter gliosis, demyelination, or increased water content. On neuroimaging, a progressive confluent subcortical and periventricular white matter disease is seen, with hypoperfusion and hypometabolism. Diffusion tensor MRI Increased water diffusivity Decreased diffusion directionality.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Gray matter is not affected in Binswanger’s disease.

questions.text: The patient presents to a casualty with quadriplegia, aphasia, and limited horizontal eye movements, with preserved consciousness. The lesion is likely to be in which of the following areas:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bilateral ventral pons The patient has quadriplegia , aphasia, and limited horizontal eye movements, with preserved consciousness pointing towards the diagnosis of Locked-in Syndrome.

Highyeild:

Locked in Syndrome/Bilateral ventral pontine syndrome- Basilar artery Quadriplegia Unable to speak or make facial expressions Absent vertical gaze Limited Horizontal gaze movement Preserved consciousness. Complete pontine and lower midbrain infarction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Bilateral dorsal medulla- Medullary syndrome would involve the involvement of vital centres and lower cranial nerves and there is no clue in this question which would point to this. Option C. Bilateral upper dorsal pons - will have 7th nerve palsy. Option D. Bilateral lower dorsal pons- will have 7th nerve palsy.
